bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, October 20, 1940

div1.p: Andrus discusses the yellow fever experiments and his own experience with inoculation.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, October 20, 1940
div1.opener:
J.H. ANDRUS
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
10-20-40
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dear General:
div1.p:
In your letter of the fifteenth you suggest that I send your
manuscript to Lambert. I know that he would enjoy reading
it and it is quite possible that he would be able to add de-
tails that would be helpful. The serious drawback is that
his eyesight is so very poor that he would be unable to read
it. In this mail I am telling him of your suggestion and
putting it up to him as to whether I send it or not. It may
be that there is someone available who could read it to him.

As for Dr. Ames' part in the work - Some time ago I wrote
a chapter called “I become a Guinea pig” which was part of a
condensed autobiography entitled “Big Moments in a Little
Life”. The chapter referred to deals, of course, with my
personal experience with Major Reed's Board. Let me hasten
to assure you that no part of this is intended for publica-
tion. It is, on the contrary, merely intended to quench any
thirst my young grandson may develop (I hope) about his
“Grand-poppie” in years to come. I would not like to have
him derive his knowledge of my yellow fever interlude from
“Yellow Jack” or any one of several other things I have read
on the subject.

Excuse me for wandering but now I'm back to Dr. Ames. In my
story is an incident that you may find worth lifting. Just
as soon as I am able to copy the chapter, will send it to you.
It is not probable that you will find much in it that you can
use but I want you to feel perfectly free to use anything you
want. There is but one copy of my effort.

When I return your manuscript you will find “I never saw Dr.
Agramonte do anything at the laboratory except confer with
the Major”. In my last letter to you I did not express what
I had in mind. The sentence I refer to should have read:
“Early in the exteriments, mosquitoes may have been been pro-
cured and innoculated by Dr. Agramonte”.

I was not detailed for duty with the Board until early October, shortly after
Dr. Lazear's death. Then, after my innoculation, a little
less than four months later, I did not return to duty with the
Board. That period was the golden hour of the experiments.

We kept no innoculated mosquitoes at the laboratory. Our job
was to furnish mosquitoes ready for innoculation. The “birds”
were selected by Major Reed or Lieutenant Carroll and taken
2.
away in test tubes. None, in my time, were ever taken away
by Dr. Agramonte. I can only guess who innoculated them.
My guess was that Dr. Agramonte MAY HAVE innoculated some of
the earlier insects at Los Animas Hospital. After Camp La-
zear was established and cases produced there, it is my guess
that mosquitoes were innoculated at the yellow fever hospital,
at Columbia Barracks, by Dr. Carroll, Major Reed or Dr. Ames.
It is my belief that infected insects were applied to volun-
teers, at Camp Lazear, by one of the same trio. I believe
that liklihood, for both operations, is in the order they are
named. (1-Carroll, 2-Reed and 3-Ames.)

I remember the cold spell and comment on it in my notes with
your manuscript.

Am enclosing a letter from Dr. Cook. Rather, answers from
him to questions I asked. It is not what I expected but may
interest you.

With reference to my innoculation, there was a slight irreg-
ularity. All other volunteers - after Dr. Carroll and Dean -
had been quarantined at Camp Lazear before their innoculation.
In my case, I had slept in the Corps men's quarters the night
before and worked in the laboratory until a few minutes before
my “shot” was given me. Then, I walked to the yellow fever
hospital and waited outside one of the wards while blood was
taken from Forbes' arm. It was injected in my arm right
there, in the open. It seems incredible but I cannot remem-
ber who made the innoculation. Until I was ready to put it
on paper I would have said it was Dr. Ames. I believe, how-
ever, that Dr. Ames was sick and in bed at the Post Hospital
at that time.

Thank you for flattering my stenographer. I'll let her read
your letter instead of giving her a “raise”. As a matter of
fact I am “her”. I have a stand rigged up to straddle my
body. The top is on an incline of about 45 degrees. The
typewriter hangs from the top, in front of me, and I use it
while flat on my back. And don't let it worry you - it is
no more tiring than as though I was up and around.

You are doing me a favor to present a subject in which I am
interested.

closer.seg:
Postscript * The photograph of hospital at Columbia Barracks
was mailed yesterday. - JHA.
